data.title: Chico Hamilton
data.meta_description: In 1952 after the baritone saxophonist Gerry Mulligan had hitchhiked across America from New York to Los Angeles, he decided to put together a chamber jazz group with no chordal instrument. He
data.text: In 1952 after the baritone saxophonist Gerry Mulligan had hitchhiked across America from New York to Los Angeles, he decided to put together a chamber jazz group with no chordal instrument. He recruited the then unknown trumpeter Chet Baker, and the bassist Bob Whitlock, and brought them to the house of drummer Chico Hamilton, who was taking time off from accompanying Lena Horne. Mulligan was emphatic that for the sound he wanted he required just a snare drum and hi-hat cymbal, with a small tom-tom to give a light bass-drum effect. Hamiltonâ€™s deft brushwork and gentle touch on this minimal set-up became a key ingredient in the sound of one of the most influential and revolutionary of all jazz groups. His place in jazz history
